occurrences.line_text: With speede vnto the place, whereas he last
And fled away with all the speede she mought,
Through hils and dales he speedie way did make,
With speedie course, as bent to charge them new.
The which with speedie pace did after them pursew.
Lo where they spyde with speedie whirling pace,
Gaue way vnto his horses speedie flying,
That made him euermore increase his speedie pace.
He vnto her would speedily reuert:
Whom seeing flie, she speedily poursewed
And Eagles wings, for scope and speedinesse,
He making speedy way through spersed ayre,
But to the easterne coast of heauen makes speedy way.
Is gathered full, and worketh speedy way:
Not fit for speedy pace, or manly exercize.
Carried away with wings of speedy feare.
Whether through swiftnesse of his speedy beast,
There was the speedy Tamar, which deuides
Speedy Hippothoe, and chaste Actea,
Ne once for ought her speedy passage stayd,
He cared not for dint of sword nor speere,
The hidden power of herbes, and might of Magicke spell?
That is the terme prescribed by the spell.
All liuing wightes in might of magicke spell:
In vaine seekes wonders out of Magicke spell.
One day of Proteus by his mightie spell,
Did him, they say, forwarne through sacred spell.
The rest my selfe too readily can spell.
With which and other spelles like terrible,
And eue[r]more with mighty spels them charmd,
Now needeth him no lenger labour spend,
In that bright shield, and all their forces spend
Many kind speeches they betwene them spend,
Did spend their dayes in doing godly thing:
His wearie pounces all in vaine doth spend,
And in Amours the passing houres to spend,
And honours suit my vowed dayes do spend,
Do rather choose my flitting houres to spend,
His dayes, his goods, his bodie he did spend:
Nor so did Biblis spend her pining hart,
He did engraue, and muchell bloud did spend,
Yet has full large to liue, and spend at libertie.
My natiue soile haue left, my dayes to spend
Did spend her dayes, and lov'd in forests wyld to space.
And maketh him his wing in vaine to spend;
Then life and labour both in vaine to spend.
His life he then would spend to iustifie his right.
Though I this dearest life for her doe spend;
Doe spend my dayes, and bend my carelesse wit
So all that day in wandring vainely he did spend.
As each thought best to spend the lingring space.
For her did languish, and his deare life spend;
But all the night in siluer sleepe I spend,
Spending his daies in dolour and despaire,
Spending their ioyous dayes and gladfull nights,
Is wisely to aduise: now day is spent;
Had spent his lampe, and brought forth dawning light,
When all this speech the liuing tree had spent,
The day is spent, and commeth drowsie night,
So forth they past, and all the way they spent
After long labours and aduentures spent,
And all her wit in secret counsels spent,
Tempestuous fortune hath spent all her spight,
All night she spent in bidding of her bedes,
And double quite, for that he on them spent,
Till she repaired haue her tackles spent,
In these sad words she spent her vtmost breath:
Night was far spent, and now in Ocean deepe
They wist their houre was spe[n]t; the[n] each to rest him hyes.
Therein haue I spent all my youthly daies,
Diuerse discourses in their way they spent,
And now by this, Cymochles howre was spent,
Great heapes of gold, that neuer could be spent:
And after spent with pride and lauishnesse,
And as in scorne of his spent stormy spight,
But true it is, that when the oyle is spent,
Vntill he quite had spent his perlous store,
Of such, as hauing all their substance spent
Which spent their looser daies in lewd delights,
Which spent in vaine, at last she told her briefe,
Of warlike puissaunce in ages spent,
Consume, till all their warlike puissaunce be spent.
Yet is the stocke not lessened, nor spent,
All that same euening she in flying spent,
He hauing through incessant trauell spent
They wayted, that the night was forward spent,
But all the while, that he these speaches spent,
That now the humid night was farforth spent,
Laught at his foolish labour spent in waste;
Adowne, as if their springes of life were spent;
And cared not to spare, that should be shortly spent.
Till th'heat of his fierce furie he had spent:
But when the floud is spent, then backe againe
Where making ioyous feast theire daies they spent
But here my wearie teeme nigh ouer spent
At last when all her speeches she had spent,
And chearelesse hunger, they together spent;
And rayl'd and rag'd, till she had all her poyson spent.
Then after many teares and sorrowes spent,
And rest themselues for to recouer spirits spent.
All which my daies I haue not lewdly spent,
When day is spent, and rest vs needeth most,
Hauing spent all her mastes and her ground-hold,
So that he now has almost spent his spright.
There they awhile some gracious speaches spent,
Effect the same, whylest all the night was spent.
Was farre forth spent, discoursing diuersly
From natiue home, and spent my youth in vaine,
In such discourses they together spent
And spent it selfe in mourning, he at last
Fidelia and Speranza virgins were,
Her younger sister, that Speranza hight,
But wise Speranza gaue him comfort sweet,
And to the Dwarfe a while his needlesse spere he gaue.
That rode in golden sell with single spere,
Where I expected one with shield and spere,
He at his first incomming, charg'd his spere
Without displeasance for to proue his spere.
His violence in vaine, and with his spere
Their swerds & speres were broke, & hauberques rent;
To sperre the gate; but that same lumpe of clay,
He making speedy way through spersed ayre,
But since faire Sunne hath sperst that lowring clowd,
And broke his sword in twaine, and all his armour sperst.
Therewith she spewd out of her filthy maw
What if within the Moones faire shining spheare?
And search the courses of the rowling spheares,
Her loftie towres vnto the starry sphere,
Emongst th'eternall spheres and lamping sky,
But is miscaried with the other Spheres.
And priuie spials plast in all his way,
And cheared well with wine and spiceree:
With balme and wine and costly spicery,
And daintie spices fetcht from furthest Ynd,
A shadie groue not far away they spide,
The knight of the Redcrosse when him he spide,
He spide with that same Faery champions page,
For on a day his wary Dwarfe had spide,
A donghill of dead carkases he spide,
That when the knight he spide, he gan aduance
Whose grieuous fall, when false Duessa spide,
To pleasures pallace; it may soone be spide,
Ere on the plaine fast pricking Guyon spide
Atin arriuing there, when him he spide,
At last he spide, where towards him did pace
Till that they spide, where towards them did pace
Had lost, he by him spide, right glad he grew,
Whenas they spide a goodly castle, plast
Now when they spide the knight to slacke his pace,
They spide a knight, that towards pricked faire,
And gifts of heauenly grace he by him spide,
He spide far off a mighty Giauntesse,
A trembling Culuer, hauing spide on hight
At length he spide, whereas that wofull Squire,
They spide, where Paridell came pricking fast
Lo thus they rode, till at the last they spide
Which faire aduenture when Cambello spide,
They spide a little cottage, like some poore mans nest.
A litle cotage farre away they spide,
At length they spide, where towards them with speed
Till at the last I spide within the same,
But soone as they him nigh approching spide,
He chaunst to come, where happily he spide
To weather his brode sailes, by chaunce hath spide
There as she looked long, at last she spide
Whom soone as Talus spide by glims of night,
Vntill she spide the lampe of lightsome day,
Certes (sayd she) sith ye so well haue spide
They spide a Lady left all succourlesse,
He spide come pricking on with al his powre and might.
Eftsoones he spide a Knight approching nye,
Soone as they spide her, Lord what gladfull glee
To see their thrids so thin, as spiders frame,
But this good knight soone as he them can spie,
And all the hinder parts, that few could spie,
The loft was raysd againe, that no man could it spie.
Where euer in the darke he could them spie;
Nor sire, nor sonnes, nor any could she spie:
Till that at length she did before her spie
He chaunst to spie a faire and stately place,
Vpon that shore he spied Atin stand,
And through their iron sides with cruell spies
And when him running in full course he spies,
The warie fowle that spies him toward bend
Her fawning loue with foule disdainefull spight
With foule reproches, and disdainfull spight
Their gay attire: each others greater pride does spight.
From dreaded storme of his disdainfull spight:
Tempestuous fortune hath spent all her spight,
The proud Duessa full of wrathfull spight,
Him therefore now the obiect of his spight
Against themselues turning their wrathfull spight,
That hath (maugre her spight) thus low me laid in dust.
His mother eke, more to augment his spight,
And calme the sea of their tempestuous spight,
Kindled through his infernall brond of spight,
Yet since no way is left to wreake my spight,
Making aduantage, to reuenge their spight,
And as in scorne of his spent stormy spight,
Pourd out their plenty, without spight or spare:
Late foule dishonour and reprochfull spight,
Such happinesse did, maulgre, to me spight,
So fell those two in spight of both their prydes,
To stirre vp strife, twixt loue and spight and ire,
And gan therefore close spight to him to beare:
But she her selfe did thinke it doen for spight,
She came of her accord, in spight of all his fone.
So when as fortune all her spight hath showne,
And then both Knights enuide, & Ladies eke did spight.
That all in spight and malice did agree,
And far from enuious eyes that mote him spight.
Or house to hide his head from heauens spight,
To weary him the more, and waste his spight,
With that they both at once with equall spight
Yet nought abating of his former spight,
Firme Chastity, that spight ne blemish dare;
And spitting forth the poyson of his spight,
He does backebite, and spightfull poison spues
O do thy cruell wrath and spightfull wrong
Now with remembrance of those spightfull speaches,
Her spightfull words did pricke, & wound the inner part.
Yet she did not her spightfull speach forbeare,
With spightfull speaches, fitting with her well;
The third nor strong nor wise, but spightfullest Defetto.
Spighting my happie freedome, haue agreed,
She scorning both their spights, does make wide way,
With point of steele, that close his hartbloud spild,
That all his vitall spirites thereby spild,
Her selfe a yeelded pray to saue or spill.
And your faire beautie do with sadnesse spill?
And many drops of milke and bloud through it did spill.
Bad her commaund my life to saue, or spill.
Beastly he threw her downe, ne car'd to spill
Ne either cared life to saue or spill,
That all his former praise doth fowly spill.
But that he seekes by traytrous traines to spill
As it is greater prayse to saue, then spill,
She could or saue, or spill, whom she would hight.
Oft spilles the principall, to saue the part;
Vpon the which she litle spinnes, but spils,
Which he had spilt, and all to rags yrent,
Shall with his owne bloud price that he hath spilt.
On which true Christians bloud was often spilt,
With pretious bloud, which cruelly was spilt
From which young Hectors bloud by cruell Greekes was spilt.
And all the others pauement were with yuory spilt.
Nor spilt the blossome of my tender yeares
More subtile web Arachne can not spin,
To spin, to card, to sew, to wash, to wring;
That he thereon should spin both flax and tow;
Yet neither spinnes nor cardes, ne cares nor frets,
Vpon the which she litle spinnes, but spils,
Spinning and carding all in comely rew,
Soft Spio, sweete Eudore, Sao sad,
Eftsoones forth looked from the highest spire
Of woman kind it fairest flowre doth spire,
More ample spirit, then hitherto was wount,
Or aerie spirit vnder false pretence,
That still it breathed forth sweet spirit & holesome smell.
So from the wearie spirit thou doest driue
And a quicke mouing Spirit did arret
From her high spirit chase imperious feare,
Then pardon, O most sacred happie spirit,
Of thine owne spirit, which doth in me suruiue,
But noysome breath, and poysnous spirit sent
And feeble spirit inly felt refection;
But he, whose spirit was with pride vpblowne,
And pangs of death her spirit ouertooke.
Looke vp at last, and wake thy dulled spirit,
By some bad spirit, that it to mischiefe bore,
That through the wound his spirit shortly did depart.
And spotlesse spirit, in which ye may enchace
And infinite desire into your spirite poure!
And then his spirite thus gan forth display;
But all in his reuenge of spirite would depriue.
Him long forbore, and still his spirite spar'd,
As ouercomen of the spirites powre,
And mighty spirites bound with mightier band,
That all his vitall spirites thereby spild,
In heauenly spirits to these creatures bace,
From th'earth, & from her wombe new spirits to reprize.
There let her with the damned spirits dwell,
And with vaine hope his spirits faint supply,
His weakned powers, and dulled spirits whet,
And haughtie spirits meekely to adaw,
And rest themselues for to recouer spirits spent.
Which in their spirits kindling zealous fire,
Gan fade, and liuely spirits deaded quight:
And feeble spirits, that gan faint and reele,
And wondrous ioy felt in her spirits thrall:
Against spirituall foes, yeelds by and by,
His mind was full of spirituall repast,
Come daughter come, come; spit vpon my face,
Spit thrise vpon me, thrise vpon me spit;
Spit thrise vpon me, thrise vpon me spit;
No spot of blame, though spite did oft assay
Ne priuate iarre, ne spite of enemis
Which spitefull words she sore engrieu'd to heare,
And spitting forth the poyson of his spight,
The swelling Splene, and Frenzy raging rife,
That he him maymed quite, and all his shoulder split.
His blessed body spoild of liuely breath,
And spoild the Priests of their habiliments,
Their kingdome spoild, and countrey wasted quight:
Spoild of their rosie red, were woxen pale and wan.
From raging spoile of lawlesse victors will?
And win rich spoile of ransackt chastetee.
But spoile her of her scarlot robe, and let her fly.
Faire sonne of Mars, that seeke with warlike spoile.
To spoile her daintie corse so faire and sheene,
Where they are well receiu'd, and made to spoile
For all in bloud and spoile is his delight.
Great glory and gay spoile sure hast thou got,
Breake in, and spoile the treasure there in gard:
Abandone soone, I read, the caitiue spoile
Of vile reuenge. To spoile the dead of weed
Vespasian, that with great spoile and rage
In hope thereof to win victorious spoile.
Ne in so glorious spoile themselues embosse;
And the spoile of the countrey conquered
But yield her selfe to spoile of greedinesse.
Now like a Lyon, hunting after spoile,
Of thy vaine boast, and spoile of loue misgotten,
They spoile and rauine without all remorse,
For on the spoile of women he doth liue,
Yet will not he the louely spoile downe lay,
Was fled to hell, surcharg'd with spoile and theft.
To whom he did diuide part of his purchast spoile.
And purchased this peerelesse beauties spoile,
And greedy seas doe in the spoile of life delight.
Then doth he take the spoile of them at will,
The Sarazin, awayting for some spoile.
The spoile of peoples euill gotten good,
That piteous spoile by so iniurious theft.
And spoile my selfe, that can not thee withstand?
Giuen to me the spoile of this dead knight,
And euermore his louely litle spoile
That seem'd the spoile of some right well renownd.
And now triumphest in the piteous spoile
That taketh vengeaunce of his peoples spoile.
Of stealth and spoile, and making nightly rode
And first they spoile her of her iewels deare,
His Loues deare spoile, in which his heart was prayde,
But fed on spoile and booty, which they made
Now made the spoile of theeues and Brigants bad,
To Fortunes spoile, vnable it to ayd.
Him follow'd, by the tract of his outragious spoile.
In which such spoile, such hauocke, and such theft
Rather then see her people spoiled quight,
Those spoilefull Picts, and swarming Easterlings,
After his murdrous spoiles and bloudy rage allayd.
And glorious spoiles, purchast in perilous fight:
Then all his wars and spoiles, the which he did of yore.
The world with murdrous spoiles and bloudie pray,
Since which, with sundrie spoiles she hath beene ransacked.
And with rich spoiles and famous victorie,
And th'amarous sweet spoiles to greedy eyes reuele.
Who when he hath with spoiles and cruelty
And pledges; as the spoiles of my victorious games.
And spoiles, wherewith he all the ground did strow,
With warlike spoiles, and with victorious prayes,
Which shar'd to them the spoiles that he had got aliue.
To lay his spoiles before his lemans traine:
He either spoiles, if they against him stand,
The spoiles of Princes hang'd, which were in battel won.
By hunting and by spoiling liued then;
With sonnes owne blade, her fowle reproches spoke;
And hearken to the sober speaches, which she spoke.
As those vnknightly raylings, which he spoke,
They forward passe, ne Guyon yet spoke word,
Thus as he spoke, loe with outragious cry
That neuer word from that day forth he spoke.
Of that same Ladie, whether what he spoke,
And Altars fouled, and blasphemy spoke,
Which thereof spoken were, she gan againe
Which first was spoken by th'Almightie lord,
As if the word so spoken, were halfe donne,
To stay their hands, till he a while had spoken:
And so likewise of words, the which be spoken,
To all, mongst whom this storie should be spoken,
Ne euer was the name of warre there spoken,
That through the clifts the vermeil bloud out sponne,
And in fresh flowring fields themselues to sport;
His cruell sport, in stead of sorrow dew;
Now faining dalliance and wanton sport,
Her to disarme, and with delightfull sport
With whom he meant to make his sport & courtly play.
The rest she fyr'd for sport, or for despight;
Saw all this goodly sport, and grieued sore,
When wearie of their sport to sleepe they fell,
His sea-horses did seeme to sport amayne,
By way of sport, as oft in maskes is knowen,
Some laught for sport, some did for wonder shout,
That masked Mock-knight was their sport and play.
But layd aside, when so she vsd her looser sport.
All these together by themselves did sport
Oft-times amo[n]gst the wanton Nymphs to sport and toy.
Amongst his peres playing his childish sport:
The whylest at pleasure she mote sport and play;
Or with the Graces there to play and sport;
After his sportes, and cruell pastime donne,
Sporting himselfe in safe felicity:
For-wearied with my sports, I did alight
Playing their sports, that ioyd her to behold,
Their wanton sports and childish mirth did play,
His wanton sports, being returned late
In louely wise, and sleepes, and sports, and playes;
A flocke of litle loues, and sports, and ioyes,
Were met, to make their sports and merrie glee,
All lilly white, withoutten spot, or pride,
Most sacred virgin, without spot of sin.
His cruell deedes and wicked wyles did spot:
No spot of blame, though spite did oft assay
That hast with shamefull spot of sinfull lust
Within his mouth a blacke spot doth appeare,
So faire and tender, without staine or spot,
To whom in perfect loue, and spotlesse fame,
Their spotlesse pleasures, and sweet loues content.
And spotlesse spirit, in which ye may enchace
With thousand spots of colours queint elect,
The spotted Panther, and the tusked Bore,
But he them spotted with reproch, or secrete shame.
But ere my hoped day of spousall shone,
Doubly supplide, in spousall, and dominion.
He would be there, and honor to her spousall ad.
In honour of the spousalls, which then were
The spousals of faire Florimell,
Though spousd, yet wanting wedlocks solemnize;
Where he her spous'd, and made his ioyous bride.
How she was found againe, and spousde to Marinell.
And seeke her spouse, that from her still does fly,
That to their heauenly spouse both sweet and braue
That I that Ladie to my spouse had wonne;
Thy spouse I will her make, if that thou lust,
The spouse of Britomart, is Arthegall:
Before the spouse: that was Arion crownd;
And borrow'd beautie spoyld. Her nathelesse
The infant, so for want of nourture spoyld:
Mongst whom a woman spoyld of all attire
And spoyld their houses, and them selues did murder;
They spoyld old Melibee of all he had,
Spoyld all our cots, and caried vs from hence?
Be wonne, to spoyle the Castle of his health?
Here haunts that feend, and does his dayly spoyle,
And his fraile eye with spoyle of beautie feedes;
Betrayd his contrey vnto forreine spoyle:
For spoyle of wretches, whose vnhappie cace,
And the rich wares to saue from pitteous spoyle,
Her snowy brest was bare to readie spoyle
Their arbers spoyle, their Cabinets suppresse,
The spoyle of all the world, that it did pas
Of spoyle and murder they gan arme byliue,
Being possessed of that spoyle, which seemed
To saue her selfe from that outrageous spoyle,
That his proud spoyle of that same dolorous
So fayre a spoyle, to make you ioyous meriment?
The couenant was, that euery spoyle or pray
And of your gotten spoyle their owne triumph to make.
Haue by good fortune found some beasts fresh spoyle,
Where beauties prize shold win that pretious spoyle:
That nought but spoyle and vengeance did require.
To spoyle so goodly workmanship of nature,
And cruell spoyle, which he had spard, to stow:
Was spoyle to make, and wast them vnto nought,
For no intreatie would forgoe so glorious spoyle.
That glorious spoyle of beautie with me lead,
The which of all her spoyle was onely left;
Should issue forth, in hope to find some spoyle,
She, glad of spoyle and ruinous decay,
The present of his paines, that Monsters spoyle,
That raskall many with vnpittied spoyle;
And wish, that he part of his spoyle might share.
Compeld him soone the spoyle adowne to lay.
Gotten by spoyle, then purchaced aright.
And hanging vp his armes and warlike spoyle,
Her selfe sole left, a second spoyle to bee
Now all vnwares, and take the spoyle away;
Th'abandond spoyle, he softly it vnbound;
To see so faire things mard, and spoyled quight:
For to haue spoyled her, when Calidore
And saw his shepheards cottage spoyled quight,
Of her rich spoyles, whom he had earst destroyd,
where Loues spoyles are exprest.
Whom they before in diuerse spoyles had caught:
And thence did all the spoyles and threasures take,
And spoyling all her geares and goodly ray,
Are met at spoyling of some hungry pray,
He on himselfe had ta'en, and rayling rymes had sprad.
And on his head an hood with aglets sprad,
These eyes him saw vpon the cold earth sprad,
Did spread their rule through all the territories,
To proue how many acres he did spread of land.
And gins to spread his leafe before the faire sunshine.
Spreading it selfe into a spatious plaine.
The spacious Shenan spreading like a sea,
The spreading Lee, that like an Island fayre
That her brode spreading wings did wyde vnfold;
Did spred so broad, that heauens light did hide,
Whiles sad Night ouer him her ma[n]tle black doth spred
And that false other Spright, on whom he spred
